p: Most of the reported studies were performed with plant leaves; however other plant parts revealed to possess antimicrobial activity. Namely, Rana et al. [ 64] evaluated the activity of catechins from underutilized tea plant parts (coarse leaves, flowers and fruits) against Gram positive and Gram negative food-borne pathogens ( B. subtilis, S. aureus, E. coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae). The best result was obtained for tea flower extract (maximum zone of inhibition at 20 mg/mL) against S. aureus and K. pneumonia.
